content:
Hello @T-compiler/meeting; last triage meeting of :two: :zero: :two: :one: will take place in about 1h45
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-async-foundations by by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry: anything to share?
  • WG-traits @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey : anything to share?
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , time for our weekly triage meeting. Add a :wave: to show you’re here!

We’ll start off with ~6 minutes for

Announcements

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copyright/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).
Whoops, I didn't write a checkin for wg-traits
That’s okay, throw it on the meeting now. :)
I think it can be summed up as "more of the same" of the previous checkins
Works for me
As for @WG-async-foundations , I think both @nikomatsakis and @tmandry are on holiday, but I might be able to summarize

a tiny thing from me. as per our prev. meetings I have submitted a pr to officially retire wg rfc-2229 from the scheduling
https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/pull/477
I am working in putting together a wg-traits retrospective blog post for the new year
the last filled-in checkin from async foundations was in october
the live document covering the async foundations springs is here

since OCtober 7th, async foundtions has: posted an RFC for static async fn in traits and for return position impl trait in traits, posted a doc on async stack traces effort, helped the tokio team with shipping tokio-console 0.1
that’s actually pretty impressive now that I’ve gone and accumlated all of it.
(there has also been effort on general purpose generators, and various bits of polish that I didn’t list.)

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: 6 months ago)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc)" compiler-team#472 (last review activity: about 20 days ago)
    • "-Dwarnings to cover all warnings" compiler-team#473 (last review activity: about 20 days ago)
    • "Build-time execution sandboxing" compiler-team#475 (last review activity: about 2 days ago)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Stabilize -Z instrument-coverage as -C instrument-coverage" rust#90132
    • "Stabilize -Z print-link-args as -C print-link-args" rust#91606

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "CI should exercise (subset of) tests under --stage 1" compiler-team#439

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.
  • Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • No new finished FCP (disposition merge) this time.

WG checkins

See above

Backport nominations

T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

• "Re-introduce concept of projection cache 'completion'" rust#89831
    • Should close P-high rust#89195
    • discussion from last week: based on @Aaron Hill concerns, decision for a backport was deferred
    • anything new to add?
Oh, there was a new MCP posted yesterday
I'm still nervous about backporting that PR
https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/476
Same tbh
(sorry, I left out a few bullets when I first transcribed it. Fixed now.)
Though, I might feel better late in the cycle
Once it's baked in nightly for a while
So, rust#89195 was already aided by PR #90423, which we did backport
The perf improvements are really significant for certain use cases but I'd also feel more comfortable just letting this ride the trains.
so does rust#89831 make things “even better” ?
Yes
@pnkfelix it's a different test case
FWIR
As usual, the pile-on from people in a single issue makes it hard to track which fixes help which things
At least for us, we still have a team with 10 minute long builds that only #89831 fixes (builds down to 40 seconds or so)
It sounds to me like there’s general consensus that we should let this ride the trains
or at least wait longer...
So maybe we decline to backport, but say that if someone renominates it, we’ll talk about it again in a later meeting?
(versus just leaving it nominated week after week…)
I’m going to go with “decline to backport for now"

• "Don't perform any new queries while reading a query result on disk" rust#91919
    • discussion from last week: this PR depends on rust#91924 and rust#92163 and seems to suffer from a significant perf. loss from them, so backporting this one doesn't look like a good option (comment from @mw)
That PR doesn't fix any ICEs, so I don't see much point in backporting it

fixed the link the comment of @mw
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/91919#issuecomment-1000401622
So my memory is that there was some confusion in the comments about whether this was an outright correctness (soundness I assume) fix
It will trigger new ICEs if queries are invoked during decoding
but it does not itself change any query decoding to stop invoking new queries
and it's not even merged to master yet
Okay. and I see now that even @mw , who was the one who nominated this for beta backport, has since noted that backporting isn’t really an option
so lets decline to backport then.

• "Re-introduce concept of projection cache 'completion'" rust#89831
    • Discussed last week, see beta backport
there’s no way this is getting stably backported IMO. Lets just outright decline that.
T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

• "Fix rustdoc::private_doc_tests lint for public re-exported items" rust#92349
    • Fixes an old rust#72081 and low priority rustdoc issue
    • Fixes a lint that produced a wrong warning on exported items
    • Waiting on CI, still not merged
    • @GuillaumeGomez suggests that this being an old issue, maybe it can flow into the next release without backport.
Yeah I don’t think we’re backporting this
the code change looks minor but I don’t think we can justify it nonetheless.
declining to beta backport.
I just realized I had forgotten to put emojis up, after coming to that conclusion that I’ve now struck out
so people can at least weigh in.
(My inclination is nonetheless to decline to backport. I’m not seeing votes for :back: )

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • "Fix invalid removal of backlines from doc comments" rust#92357
    • fixes rustdoc issue (rust#91201)
    • PR introduces a small breaking change as it slightly changes the output of rustdoc
    • T-rustdoc seem to be ok with the change see rustdoc discussion
what’s a “backline” ?
I think they mean \ paragraph breaks

@GuillaumeGomez suggests that this being an old issue, maybe it can flow into the next release without backport.

Just in case, I re-confirm it.
Hmm. Okay
@Noah Lev says they opened a conversation on zulip here: https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/266220-rustdoc/topic/stop.20trimming.20newlines.20from.20doc.20strings
This seems fine for me

(I’m trying to think of what an analogous change would be for the language itself. I guess it would be fixing “obvious bugs”, even if they are breaking changes. I don’t think rustdoc needs to have the analogous notion of a warning-cycle though, not for something like this, unless the rustdoc team wanted it.)
So, yeah
I updated the labels accordingly

Oldest PRs waiting for review

T-compiler

• "Let qpath contain NtTy: <$:ty as $:ty>::…" #91150 (last activity: 1 month ago)
    • assigned to @Wesley Wiser
    • previously reviewed by @Vadim Petrochenkov
It sounds like the @Vadim Petrochenkov retraced their objects in the comment thread
and this was auto-assigned to @Wesley Wiser
Is this just waiting on review then? Nothing special?
I don’t think there’s anything special, but maybe someone other than @Wesley Wiser should grab it?
Yeah, this is a part of the compiler I’m unfamiliar with.
the fact that @Vadim Petrochenkov has already looked over it means that I think its a candidate for anyone to review, even people who are not famiilar with that part of the compiler
though maybe @Vadim Petrochenkov was only looking at the abstract specification of what was changing, and not the code itself, to be fair.
It is a reasonably small code change
lets move along, either @Wesley Wiser can keep it, or @Wesley Wiser can ask for someone else to take it.

• "Extend check for UnsafeCell in consts to cover unions" #90383 (last activity: about 2 months ago)
    • Assigned to @RalfJ, perhaps needs a second round of review?
Its too bad that @RalfJ is not subscribed to this stream. :)
It sounds ike this should stay with @RalfJ . Who else would we give it to, maybe @oli ?
I’ll send a privmsg to @RalfJ double checking if they’ll get back to it.
next

• Remove NullOp::Box by nbdd0121 · Pull Request #90102 · rust-lang/rust
    • opened by @Gary Guo
    • reviewed by @RalfJ, approved by @oli
    • What's the actual status of this PR?
Hunh
I wonder if @oli was deliberately not writing @bors r+
on PR #90102
because they wanted @RalfJ to get a chance to look over it again
I’ll add this to my priv msg to Ralf
The PR that it follows up is reviewed by jonas-schievink so this PR is assigned to him as well.
But I guess if he's not responsive this could be reassigned to a different reviewer
that’s true, I overlooked that
to be honest I’m guessing if it were just @oli and @Jonas Schievink [he/him] , I think @oli would have just marked @bors r+
its the presence of @RalfJ in this PR that makes me wonder about @oli ’s intent.
In any case, I know @oli is on holiday until January
so nothing will happen there in the short term
(not that January is that far away! Happy New Year Y’all)
Yeah, it's a tough week for getting people to chime in
lets move along, nonetheless

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 2 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 79 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 53 of those are unassigned
  • 1 P-critical, 1 P-high, 0 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 2 P-medium, 1 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 2 P-critical, 52 P-high, 82 P-medium, 13 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "Compile-time regression between 1.56.1 and 1.57.0 for deeply nested decorator types" rust#91598
    • Some of the compile time regression has been recovered in latest nightlies, though we're not back at the 1.56.1 level (see @Aaron Hill comment)
    • Relevant PR rust#91186 is progressing and being reviewed
    • #91186 discussed in meeting and maybe a candidate for a beta-backport (see Zulip mention)
    • perhaps backport not as it is (see @The 8472 comment)

perhaps backport not as it is (see @The 8472 comment)

The opposite. I think as it is it would be ok. Refactoring would make it larger in scope.
what is status for PR #91186 landing in nightly?
Wait does #91186 also fix perf issues not fixed by previous PRs?
at this point I’m more concerned about addressing the initial landing in nightly, rather than worrying about backport Q
I.e. this one
@Jack Huey are you asking if #91598 is already resolved in current nightly?
Yes
I'm guessing no
a recent comment claims latest nightly does not address their issue
But tbh I forgot about this PR
PR #91186 currently assigned to @Esteban Küber , who is on holiday
There's a similar but smaller PR open by @lcnr
Has that been tested again the issue?
@Jack Huey pointer?
One sec
#84944
hunh
that only seems to remove deduplication unless github is showing me the wrong diff
so PR #84944 is blocked because people have concerns that it may introduced exponential blowup that is not covered by our test/perf suites
Oh I see
Okay, well, I'll take a look at #91186
You’ve got time to look at it, @Jack Huey ? That would be awesome
Yes
Okay great
Interactions like this are what remind me that this is why we do the review of the critical issues, et cetera

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • No P-high beta regressions this time.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs for 2021-12-28

Relatively quiet week, mostly rustdoc improvements.

Triage done by @simulacrum.
Revision range: 3d57c61a9e04dcd3df633f41142009d6dcad4399..e91ad5fc62bdee4a29c18baa5fad2ca42fc91bf4

2 Regressions, 1 Improvements, 6 Mixed; 0 of them in rollups
0 Untriaged PRs
26 comparisons made in total

Regressions

Fix bad caching of ~const Drop bounds #92149

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 2.6% on incr-patched: println builds of regression-31157)
  • Necessary fix for correctness.

Add #[inline] modifier to TypeId::of #92135

  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 4.4% on full builds of keccak)
  • Reverted in a later pull request, unclear what the exact cause of the
    regression is.

Improvements

  • :arrow_up: rust-analyzer #92247
  • Remove PartialOrd, Ord from LocalDefId #90408
  • Do not display ~const Drop in rustdoc #92229
  • Rustdoc: use is_doc_hidden method on more places #92227
  • intra-doc: Use an enum to represent URL fragments #92088
  • rustc_metadata: Switch crate data iteration from a callback to iterator #92159

Mixed

Backport LLVM changes to disable deferred inlining #92110

  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -8.3% on incr-patched: println builds of regression-31157)
  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 2.8% on full builds of deeply-nested)
  • Avoids an extreme regression in LLVM, which was blocking migration onto the
    new pass manager (and so newer rustc versions) for some crates.

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

  • No nominated issues for T-compiler this time.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
Okay, great, that’s the agenda
while I happen to have so many people here, I wanted to ask a workflow question
I’ve been trying to dissect a nasty LLVM bug
involving LTO
Issue #91671
Here’s my Question: I’ve got a repro.sh script that involves building three crates. We segfault on the third build.
what I would like is to reduce that into something that I can file with the LLVM folks. I.e. LLVM-IR files
I can do —emit llvm-ir for the first two builds, but I’m not sure what I should do to process that output into something that the third invocation will use
/me looks at the repro.sh script and realizes that he should push the updated version that targets aarch64 Linux rather than Darwin
Well, we’re out of time. I’ll post my question in #t-compiler/wg-llvm maybe.
Thanks for attending y’all! Have a great function prologue into 2022! :calendar:
This topic was moved here from #t-compiler/meetings > [weekly] 2021-12-30 #54818 by pnkfelix
This topic was moved by pnkfelix to #t-compiler/wg-llvm > translating multi-crate build into LLVM IR
This topic was moved by pnkfelix to #t-compiler/wg-llvm > translating multi-crate build into LLVM IR

Draft for next weeks' agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/AIFRkceiTmWroen0HV5mEw?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli
  • WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi

apiraino said:

Draft for next weeks' agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/AIFRkceiTmWroen0HV5mEw?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-diagnostics by Esteban Küber and oli
  • WG-rustc-dev-guide by Santiago Pastorino and Yuki Okushi

I'm on vacations, @Yuki Okushi can you fill the check in?
yeah, happy to do that :)
